title: Order Harpacticoida
text:
Harpacticoids are distinguished by: - very short antennae - wider urosome relative to other orders - short, splayed caudal rami

All taxa of Harpacticoida in the Bay-Delta are identified as Harpacticoid UnID.
There are two known species in CDFW samples: - Tigriopus californicus - Harpacticella spp.

title: References
text: Tina Enderlin, CDFW. Tina’s Rotifer Identification Guide. 2014

title: Zooplankton Identification and Culturing
text:
Introduction
Zooplankton are key to nutrient transfer between higher and lower trophic levels in aquatic systems (Banse 1995) and their distribution can indicate environmental conditions (. Understanding the presence of zooplankton in the Delta region can help us understand trends in food availability for fishes of concern and ecosystem health.

title: Zooplankton Classifications
text:
Zooplankton taxa
Classes of micro-zooplankton:

Branchiopoda
Maxillopoda

Our taxa of interest:

Branchiopoda:

Cladocera

Maxillopoda:

Copepoda

Rotifera (Phylum)

Grouping ID and culturing separate from each other

title: Genus Oithona
text: Identification

title: Genus Oithona
text:
Oithona
There are two species of Oithona in the Delta region:

Oithona davisae
Oithona similis

This genus contains:

high salinity cyclopoid copepods
small relative to other copepods: 0.47 mm - 1 mm

other copepods typically are 0.8 mm - 2.0 mm

title: Genus Oithona
text:
Oithona similis

males size range 0.6 mm - 0.7 mm; females 0.7 mm - 1.0 mm (Scripps Institute of Oceanography)
longer antennae
very rare to find in pump samples

only 38 identifications in pump samples from 2010-2022


 
Scripps Institute of Oceanography, Dawson and Knatz 1980

title: Order Cyclopoida
text:
Cyclopoid
Cyclopoids are one of the three copepod orders found in the Bay-Delta.

Calanoida, Cyclopoida, and Harpacticoida are found in brackish-freshwater.
Cyclopoids are defined by these characteristics:

Teardrop shaped body
Antennae short-medium sized (usually shorter than prosome)
5th leg on urosome
adult males have 2 kinked antennae


Photos: Lavens & Sorgeloos 1999

Santhosh et al. 2019
Male and Females are distinguishable by size and body form. Male cyclopoids have kinked antennae and are smaller in size. See Invertebrates of the Bay-Delta Region
Cyclopoids that are counted in CDFW zooplankton pump samples include:

Limnoithona tetraspina adults
Limnoithona sinensis adults
Limnoithona spp. copepodites
Oithona davisae adults
Oithona similis adults
Oithona copepodites
Other cyclopoid copepodites

Cyclopoids counted in CB samples include:

all adults listed above
Acanthocyclops vernalis
Other cylopoid adults


References:
Lavens, P. and Sorgeloos, P. (1996). Manual on the Production and Use of Live Food for Aquaculture. FAO Fisheries Technical Paper No. 361, Rome.
Khodami, Sahar & McArthur, J. & Blanco-Bercial, Leocadio & Martinez Arbizu, Pedro. (2017). Molecular Phylogeny and Revision of Copepod Orders (Crustacea: Copepoda). Scientific Reports. 7. 10.1038/s41598-017-06656-4

title: Genus Limnoithona
text:
Limnoithona
There are two species of this genus in the Delta:

Limnoithona tetraspina
Limnoithona sinensis

This group is characterized by:

small cyclopoid copepods, up to 0.55 mm (Barroso do Abiahy 2006; Ferrari & Orsi 1984)
long caudal rami and setae
longer antennae compared to other cyclopoids

title: Genus Limnoithona
text:
Limnoithona tetraspina



very small cyclopoid found in low (not 0) salinity zones
Smooth body segments
Pointed top of metasome
Spines laterally at end of each sterna – hence “tetraspina”








Limnoithona tetraspina Female


Falavigna & Ferrari 2007

L. tetraspina adult male and female, genital somite highlighted

title: Genus Limnoithona

Limnoithona sinensis



found in freshwater
Lobed body segments, curved from the sides
Wider top of metasome

title: Genus Pseudodiaptomus
text:
Calanoid copepod with short, splayed rami - strong spines on end of rami
Pseudodiaptomus forbesii and Pseudodiaptomus marinus
Distinguishable by metasomal segments

Pseudodiaptomus forbesii
First metasomal segment >50% metasomal length

gravid females have two egg sacs

Pseudodiaptomus marinus
First metasomal segment <50% metasomal length

gravid females have one egg sac

title: Order Calanoida
text:
Calanoida
This order of copepods are characterized by:

Large
Sausage-shaped body
Long antennae (longer than prosome)


There are many calanoids in the Delta:

Acartia spp.
Acartiella spp.
Diaptomus spp.
Eurytemora affinis
Osphranticum spp.
Pseudodiaptomus forbesi
Pseudodiaptomus marinus
Sinocalanus doerri
Tortanus spp.

Each genus (will have) their separate page

title: Synchaeta
text:
There are two identified taxa in the Bay-Delta:

Synchaeta spp. unidentified
Synchaeta bicornis


Synchaeta spp.
There are a few body forms. They can be retracted or in their ‘creeping’ or ‘feeding’ form.
When preserved, Synchaeta are typically retracted into a ball.




Retracted form









Creeping form


Characterized by their four long sensory bristles, pointed corona with two projections.

title: Phylum Rotifera
text:
A Phylum, with poorly resolved relationships
There are many rotifers identified in pump samples:
Keratella spp.
Asplancha spp.
Trichocera spp.
Synchaeta spp.
--> Synchaeta bicornis
Polyarthra spp.
There are other (less common) rotifers that processors include in a lumped category called “Other rotifers.”
This information was made possible with information from Tina Enderlin’s rotifer guide and ICF’s Rotifer Guide.
The following pages will include detailed descriptions and images of each rotifer.

title: Oithona davisae culturing
text:
Distribution

Smithsonian Environmental Research Center
O. davisae is native to Japan region, but has colonized other temparate marine waters.









Bashevkin et al. 2023










Salinity range:
Lowest found: 0.1 PSU in the field (Sakaguchi et al. 2011)
Prefers salinities above 12 PSU (Ferrari and Orsi 1984), highest experimentally 40 PSU (Svetlichny and Hubareva 2014)

title: Zooplankton Identification and Culturing
section: Zooplankton Imaging Project Reference Library Development
text:
Zooplankton Imaging Project Reference Library Development

Purpose of making this guide
My position as the Environmental Scientist on the USBR-CDFW Zooplankton Imaging Project (ZIP) is to bring taxonomic expertise in the development of zooplankton image libraries to identify and count zooplankton using a fluid imaging system.
A large image reference library is required for a deep-learning model to select identifying traits for each taxa. This requires expert verification of each image.
I’m creating this document as a resource to collect all of the identification resources I have found, and show distinguishing traits of key taxa we find in Bay Delta samples for CDFW.


How will we obtain enough individuals for the model?
To obtain a large image reference library, we will be culturing target species, separating by life stage, and running through the fluid imaging system.
This requires an understanding of zooplankton:

distribution
preferred conditions (salinity, temperature, light schedule)
morphology

title: Zooplankton Identification and Culturing
text:
References
Banse K. Zooplankton: pivotal role in the control of ocean production, ICES Journal of Marine Science, 1995, vol. 52 (pg. 265-277).
zooplankton overview infromation: Philippe Grosjean, Marc Picheral, Caroline Warembourg, Gabriel Gorsky, Enumeration, measurement, and identification of net zooplankton samples using the ZOOSCAN digital imaging system, *ICES Journal of Marine Science*, Volume 61, Issue 4, 2004, Pages 518--525, [https://doi.org/10.1016/j.icesjms.2004.03.012](#0)
As well, zooplankton samples are typically dyed using Rose Bengal, but the FlowCam best photographs identifying traits when samples are undyed.
